metadata.name: Legal, Policy & Legislative Framework Database
metadata.description: Comprehensive legal constraints for ecosystem restoration recommendations

un_convention_biodiversity.name: UN Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD)

kunming_montreal_2022.target_2: 30% of degraded ecosystems under effective restoration by 2030
kunming_montreal_2022.target_3: 30% of land and sea areas protected by 2030
kunming_montreal_2022.relevance: Restoration projects contribute to national CBD commitments

implications: Frame restoration as contributing to national CBD targets
Track biodiversity outcomes, not just area restored
Prioritize sites with high biodiversity value

un_decade_ecosystem_restoration.name: UN Decade on Ecosystem Restoration (2021-2030)
principles: Effective contribution to Sustainable Development Goals

sdg_alignment.sdg_15: Life on Land (restore degraded land, halt biodiversity loss)

endangered_species_act.name: Endangered Species Act (ESA)

key_provisions.section_7: Federal agency consultation for listed species
key_provisions.section_9: Prohibition on take of listed species
key_provisions.section_10: Incidental take permits for non-federal actions

constraints: No actions that harm listed species or critical habitat
Section 7 consultation required for federal projects
Habitat Conservation Plans may be required

clean_water_act.name: Clean Water Act (CWA)

key_provisions.section_404: Permits for discharge of dredged or fill material into waters
key_provisions.section_402: NPDES permits for point source discharges

constraints: Section 404 permit required for wetland fill/dredging
Avoid and minimize impacts to waters of the US
implications_for_restoration: Stream restoration needs Army Corps consultation
Riparian buffers must meet water quality standards

nepa.name: National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA)

requirements.categorical_exclusion: Routine actions with no significant impact

constraints: Public comment periods for EAs and EISs

wilderness_act.name: Wilderness Act of 1964
wilderness_act.definition: Untrammeled, where man is a visitor who does not remain
constraints_for_restoration: No planting without Minimum Requirements Analysis
Hand tools only, no chainsaws except fire emergency

national_historic_preservation_act.name: National Historic Preservation Act (NHPA)

key_provisions.section_106: Federal undertakings require review for historic properties

constraints: Tribal consultation for traditional cultural properties

america_30x30.name: America the Beautiful (30x30) Initiative
america_30x30.target: Conserve 30% of US lands and waters by 2030
implications: Align with state and tribal conservation plans

ceqa.name: California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA)

requirements.categorical_exemption: Types of projects exempt from review

exemptions_for_restoration: Class 4: Minor alteration to land (some restoration)
Statutory exemption for some fire prevention
constraints: Most restoration projects need CEQA compliance
Public notice and comment periods apply

california_endangered_species_act.name: California Endangered Species Act (CESA)
california_endangered_species_act.agency: California Department of Fish and Wildlife (CDFW)
constraints: Separate from federal ESA (both may apply)
CDFW consultation for impacts to listed species

lake_streambed_alteration.name: Lake and Streambed Alteration Agreement
lake_streambed_alteration.trigger: Any activity that may substantially divert or obstruct natural flow or substantially change the bed, channel, or bank of any river, stream, or lake
constraints: Notification to CDFW required before work
implications_for_restoration: Erosion control work near streams needs notification
Planting in riparian zone may trigger review

california_30x30.name: California 30x30 Initiative
california_30x30.target: Conserve 30% of California's land and coastal waters by 2030

cal_vtp.name: California Vegetation Treatment Program (CalVTP)
cal_vtp.description: Statewide PEIR allowing streamlined CEQA for vegetation treatments

fpic.name: Free, Prior, and Informed Consent (FPIC)
fpic.source: UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples (UNDRIP)
fpic.definition: Indigenous peoples have the right to give or withhold consent to projects affecting their lands and resources
key_principles: FREE: Consent given voluntarily, without coercion
PRIOR: Consent obtained before project begins
INFORMED: Full information provided in accessible format
CONSENT: Right to say no, not just consultation
constraints_absolute: NEVER recommend restoration on tribal lands without explicit FPIC
Flag all projects in/near indigenous territories
Default to community-led restoration, not top-down planning

tribal_consultation.name: Government-to-Government Consultation
requirements: Federal agencies must consult with tribes on significant actions
Consider tribal treaty rights and traditional uses
implications_for_restoration: Identify culturally significant plants and sites

data_sovereignty.name: Indigenous Data Sovereignty
principles: CARE Principles: Collective benefit, Authority, Responsibility, Ethics
Indigenous communities have rights over data about their lands
constraints: Do not collect data on tribal lands without permission
Share benefits of data analysis with communities

california_tribes.name: California Native American Tribes
california_tribes.context: California has over 100 federally recognized tribes and many non-federally recognized groups
relevant_policies: California AB 52 (2014): Tribal consultation in CEQA
California SB 18 (2004): Consultation on cultural places
California Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act
implications: Many fire-affected areas are ancestral lands
Tribes are key partners in restoration

examples: Microhabitat variation not visible in satellite data
mitigation: Frame as DECISION SUPPORT, not autonomous decision-making
ALWAYS require expert validation before implementation

displacement_of_local_knowledge.risk: Traditional ecological knowledge not captured in satellite data
examples: Indigenous burning practices more effective than AI suggestions
Local landowners know specific site conditions
Community has historical knowledge of ecosystem change
mitigation: Recommend community consultation as MANDATORY step
Frame AI as COMPLEMENTARY to local knowledge, not replacement
Include TEK integration points in workflow

examples: Introduction of species that become invasive

misuse_prevention.risk: Tool used for greenwashing, land grabs, or displacement
examples: Restoration claims used to displace communities
Carbon offset projects violating indigenous rights
mitigation: Clear terms of use and ethical guidelines
Built-in checks for indigenous land overlap

geographic_bias.issue: High-resolution data more available in wealthy regions
geographic_bias.mitigation: Acknowledge data limitations, use consistent data sources

temporal_bias.issue: More recent data for some areas than others
temporal_bias.mitigation: Use consistent time periods, note temporal gaps

cloud_cover_bias.issue: Tropical regions harder to image due to clouds
cloud_cover_bias.mitigation: Aggregate data across seasons, note cloud-affected areas

classification_bias.issue: Models trained on Western ecosystems may fail elsewhere
classification_bias.mitigation: Validate locally, use transfer learning, acknowledge limitations
